awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  RATIONALES UNDERLYING AND SHAPING PLEA DECISION-MAKING
awd_abstract_narration:
The reality is that "criminal justice today is for the most part a system of pleas, not a system of trials," as Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote for the majority in Lafler v. Cooper (2012). Despite this heavy reliance on plea bargaining in the U.S. criminal justice system, the nature of plea bargain decisions remains elusive. Although there has been influential and important research in which defendants and court actors were interviewed about the plea decision process, this research was mostly conducted 30 to 40 years ago about a different court system than the one that exists today. Since then, much about courts and the process and prevalence of plea bargaining has changed. This project begins to fill this gap through semi-structured interviews with defendants, defense attorneys, and prosecutors to investigate how defendants perceive and understand the choices and imperatives with which they are faced as they navigate the legal system. The broader impact of this project is to shed light on how internal (individual-specific) and external (system-specific) rationales affect plea decision-making and how perceptions of defendants' rationales can inform the prosecutor's plea offer and the defense attorney's advice to their clients, as well as their negotiating strategies with one another.

The focus of this research is to triangulate and examine the factors affecting, and rationales underlying, the plea decision from the points of view of the defendant, defender, and prosecutor. Whereas interviews with defendants will examine their experiences and perceptions surrounding a specific case in which they pled guilty, defense attorneys and prosecutors will be interviewed more generally about their perceptions of generic defendants' rationales for their plea decisions as well as how those perceptions inform either the plea offer or the advice about accepting the offer. All interviews will be semi-structured, include parallel hypothetical scenarios for comparison between the three groups, and incorporate both open- and closed-ended questions to ensure a similar and comparable question-response structure. These open-ended responses will be examined using an inductive and systematic approach, and will be rooted in grounded and phenomenological theories. This will allow for observation and documentation of multiple possible patterns, themes, and concepts that account for variability in plea bargaining processes. In addition, to make this research more generalizable and comparable with research from several decades ago, the co-principal investigator will also use past research related to plea decision-making to develop a reliable coding scheme with which to code and analyze the open-ended interview responses in this study. Findings will be disseminated as a series of practitioner and scholarly articles, reports, and conference presentations portraying the rationales, factors, and perceptions underlying plea decision-making. Ultimately, this research will allow for further examination into legal decision-making, attorney-client and defender-prosecutor relationships, and procedural justice as it relates to contextualizing the plea negotiation process

por.por_cntn:
This qualitative study explored plea bargaining and adjudication in two Upstate NY counties: County A and County B. Data for this project was collected in two overlapping phases. The first phase contextualized the second.

In the first phase, I conducted a courtnography -- ethnography of the courts --through 160+ hours of observations in 13 (county, city, town, and village) courts in the two counties, accompanied by unstructured conversations (field interviews) with members of these courtroom workgroups (CWs). This phase focused on learning about local politics and courthouse customs, practices, and processes involved in the adjudication and negotiation of pleas.

In the second phase, I systematically sampled and conducted semi-structured interviews with 34 defendants and 28 defense attorneys and/or prosecutors across the two counties to triangulate the processes and decision rationales involved in plea adjudication. Interviews with the attorneys were particularly rich because many had experience working in multiple attorney roles (e.g., simultaneously a part-time public/conflict defender and private attorney in County B), including on both sides of the adversarial system (e.g., prosecutor in County B switches to a court-appointed and/or privately-retained attorney in County A).

Plea negotiations are complex, the adjudicative process is not linear, and "neat" representations of the decisions made can overshadow the nuances at play. To that end, I assessed the major plea considerations from the perspectives of prosecutors, defenders, and defendants. I analyzed these data using inductive and deductive methods, including grounded theory to identify key themes, patterns, and concepts at the onset and then used past court research to inform further analyses.

At the environmental, organizational, and individual levels, the role of politics is the most salient difference between the counties. Findings indicate that local legal culture (LLC) informs most facets of plea negotiation structures, strategies, processes, and practices. At the individual and organizational levels, particularly regarding differences between town, village, city, and county courts, LLCs and CWs are informed greatly by: (1) levels and types of connections between CW members and their communities; (2) convenience and efficiency of court locations and operations; (3) formality of courts and court actors; (4) presence of horizontal vs. vertical defense representation and/or prosecution; and (5) CW insider vs. outsider status, and how that informs availability of information and negotiation strategies.

Attorney perspectives of key LLC features were: (1) CW relationships and avoiding conflict (i.e., insider-outsider status and benefits/obstacles stemming from close ties within CWs/LLCs); (2) perceptions of attorney orientations surrounding pleas/trials (i.e., trial-seekers/trial-positive vs. plea-seekers/trial-avoidant attorneys); (3) differences between lawyer vs. non-lawyer judges; and (4) attorneys switching between positions as prosecutors and defense attorneys (generally, prosecution to defense).

The following were overarching plea considerations that emerged from attorney interviews: (1) distinguishing between defendant preferences vs. legal decisions defendants can make; (2) leveraging front-end vs. back-end negotiation strategies; (3) viability and practicality of going to trial; (4) using creative bargaining to avoid collateral consequences; (5) differences between negotiating felonies, misdemeanors, "misdelony-felomeanors", and violations; (6) collateral effects of using orders of protection as both a "sword and shield"; (7) negotiating plea packages by rolling cases together, including strategies/considerations for more favorable plea packages under differing circumstances and logistics of multi-jurisdictional vs. within-jurisdictional negotiations; and (8) time-based negotiation strategies, including the importance of time as a tool for managing client expectations, time efficiencies and the pace of justice (as an obstacle-course or assembly-line), time to let case files get to the bottom of the prosecutors pile, time as a mechanism against coerced or short-sighted pleas, time-served sentencing issues, time to pay (restitution, bail, fines, fees), and failure to pay which can exacerbate the case under way. Undoubtedly, the importance of time as a plea strategy (for prosecution and defense) was the most salient across attorney interviews.

Defendants discussed the following as major issues surrounding the adjudicative plea process in their recent case(s): (1) role of case outcomes, the process being the punishment, and plea (dis)satisfaction and need for "satisficing"; (2) (not)understanding proceedings, (in)ability to self-advocate, and perceived lack of agency; and (3) role of attorney-client relationships. Several underlying issues surrounding the decision to plead emerged, particularly the theme of plea bargaining in the shadows of: trial (as an option); felony indictments to county court; long-term vs. short-term considerations of liberty; time-served sentences; orders of protection; and victim cooperation. Defendants stressed the importance of avoiding surveillance-based sentences such as jail or probation, engaging in creative negotiations, and not rushing the process or pleading too quickly. The attorneys picked up on each of these as important plea considerations for defendants, particularly the importance of defendants feeling good about the plea and/or process.

This study expands the existing research surrounding what we "know" about adjudication processes and plea decision-making. Ultimately, this study and its materials can be used as a tool for future research and policy examining organizational and individual decision-making in the courts.
